problem: The function $f(n)$ satisfies $f(1) = 1$ and $f(2n + 1) = f(n) + 1$ for $n \ge 0.$  Find $f(15).$
solution:
Setting $n = 1,$ we get
\[f(3) = f(1) + 1 = 2.\]Setting $n = 3,$ we get
\[f(7) = f(3) + 1 = 3.\]Setting $n = 7,$ we get
\[f(15) = f(7) + 1 = \boxed{4}.\]
model_solution:
Step 1: Substitute $n = 7$ into the equation $f(2n + 1) = f(n) + 1$ to obtain $f(15) = f(7) + 1$.
Step 2: Substitute $n = 3$ into the equation $f(2n + 1) = f(n) + 1$ to obtain $f(7) = f(3) + 1.$
Step 3: Substitute $n = 1$ into the equation $f(2n + 1) = f(n) + 1$ to obtain $f(3) = f(1) + 1$.
Step 4: Substitute $n = 1$ into the equation $f(2n + 1) = f(n) + 1$ to obtain $f(3) = f(1) + 1$, which can be rewritten as $f(3) = 1 + 1$.
Step 5: Substitute $f(3) = 2$ into the equation from Step 2 to obtain $f(7) = 2 + 1$, so $f(7) = 3$.
Step 6: Substitute $f(7) = 3$ into the equation from Step 1 to obtain $f(15) = 3 + 1$, so $f(15) = 4$.
Step 7: 
$f(15) = f(7) + 1 = 3 + 1$
Step 8: 
$f(7) = f(3) + 1 = 2 + 1$
$f(3) = f(1) + 1 = 1 + 1$
$f(3) = 1 + 1$
steps: Step 1: Substitute $n = 7$ into the equation $f(2n + 1) = f(n) + 1$ to obtain $f(15) = f(7) + 1$.
Step 2: Substitute $n = 3$ into the equation $f(2n + 1) = f(n) + 1$ to obtain $f(7) = f(3) + 1.$
Step 3: Substitute $n = 1$ into the equation $f(2n + 1) = f(n) + 1$ to obtain $f(3) = f(1) + 1$.
Step 4: Substitute $n = 1$ into the equation $f(2n + 1) = f(n) + 1$ to obtain $f(3) = f(1) + 1$, which can be rewritten as $f(3) = 1 + 1$.
Step 5: Substitute $f(3) = 2$ into the equation from Step 2 to obtain $f(7) = 2 + 1$, so $f(7) = 3$.
Step 6: Substitute $f(7) = 3$ into the equation from Step 1 to obtain $f(15) = 3 + 1$, so $f(15) = 4$.
full_steps: Step 1: Substitute $n = 7$ into the equation $f(2n + 1) = f(n) + 1$ to obtain $f(15) = f(7) + 1$.
Step 2: Substitute $n = 3$ into the equation $f(2n + 1) = f(n) + 1$ to obtain $f(7) = f(3) + 1.$
Step 3: Substitute $n = 1$ into the equation $f(2n + 1) = f(n) + 1$ to obtain $f(3) = f(1) + 1$.
Step 4: Substitute $n = 1$ into the equation $f(2n + 1) = f(n) + 1$ to obtain $f(3) = f(1) + 1$, which can be rewritten as $f(3) = 1 + 1$.
Step 5: Substitute $f(3) = 2$ into the equation from Step 2 to obtain $f(7) = 2 + 1$, so $f(7) = 3$.
Step 6: Substitute $f(7) = 3$ into the equation from Step 1 to obtain $f(15) = 3 + 1$, so $f(15) = 4$.
